title: REMS Score (Rapid Emergency Medicine Score)
description: Emergency department mortality risk prediction score using six physiological and demographic variables. REMS is an attenuated version of APACHE II that allows for prompt calculation and has been validated across multiple patient populations including sepsis, trauma, COVID-19, and general emergency department patients.

parameters.name: heart_rate
parameters.description: Heart rate in beats per minute

parameters.name: respiratory_rate
parameters.description: Respiratory rate in breaths per minute

ranges.interpretation: REMS Score 0-2 points. Very low risk of in-hospital mortality (0.3%). Standard care and monitoring appropriate.
REMS Score 3-5 points. Low risk of in-hospital mortality (2%). Close monitoring recommended.
REMS Score 6-9 points. Moderate risk of in-hospital mortality (6.7%). Enhanced monitoring and prompt intervention indicated.
REMS Score 10-11 points. High risk of in-hospital mortality (20.3%). Intensive monitoring and aggressive intervention required.
REMS Score 12-21 points. Very high risk of in-hospital mortality (>20%). Critical care management and intensive intervention required.
REMS Score 22-26 points. Extremely high risk of in-hospital mortality (approaching 100%). Palliative care considerations may be appropriate.

references: Olsson T, Terent A, Lind L. Rapid Emergency Medicine score: a new prognostic tool for in-hospital mortality in nonsurgical emergency department patients. J Intern Med. 2004;255(5):579-587. doi: 10.1111/j.1365-2796.2004.01321.x.
Goodacre S, Turner J, Nicholl J. Prediction of mortality among emergency medical admissions. Emerg Med J. 2006;23(5):372-375. doi: 10.1136/emj.2005.028522.
Imhoff BF, Thompson NJ, Hastings MA, et al. Rapid Emergency Medicine Score (REMS) in the trauma population: a retrospective study. BMJ Open. 2014;4(5):e004738. doi: 10.1136/bmjopen-2013-004738.

Chuang CL, Tsai KC, Wu CL, et al. The utility of the rapid emergency medicine score (REMS) compared with SIRS, qSOFA and NEWS for predicting in-hospital mortality among patients with suspicion of sepsis in an emergency department. BMC Emerg Med. 2021;21(1):2. doi: 10.1186/s12873-020-00396-x.
formula: REMS Score = Age points + Body temperature points + Mean arterial pressure points + Heart rate points + Respiratory rate points + Oxygen saturation points + Glasgow Coma Scale points. Maximum score: 26 points.
notes: REMS is an attenuated version of APACHE II designed for rapid calculation in emergency settings
Validated in multiple patient populations including sepsis, trauma, COVID-19, and general emergency department patients
Higher scores indicate worse prognosis and increased mortality risk
Score ≥10 indicates high risk requiring intensive monitoring and intervention
REMS has shown superior or comparable performance to other emergency scoring systems like NEWS, qSOFA, and SIRS
Every point increase in REMS score is associated with a 40% increase in odds of in-hospital mortality
Particularly useful for early risk stratification and triage decisions in emergency departments
Can be calculated quickly using readily available clinical parameters
